2小时前

英国正式宣布对俄罗斯实施新制裁

英国政府已正式透露对俄罗斯实施更多制裁，目标是盗窃和转售乌克兰谷物、主要能源和武器运输公司，以及与俄罗斯国有核能公司 Rosatom 有关的“生产先进材料和技术”的企业。

新名称涵盖 86 名个人和公司。

英国政府还确认了正在日本参加七国集团峰会的首相 Rishi Sunak 的声明，他表示英国将禁止从俄罗斯进口钻石、铜、铝和镍。

在 G-7 讨论后，英国及其 G-7 盟友将披露对俄罗斯的新制裁，以减少克里姆林宫的金库并阻止莫斯科在全面入侵乌克兰方面取得进展。

— Ruxandra Iordache

2小时前

英国表示，俄罗斯火车事故可能会中断对莫斯科车队的供应

英国国防部在其每日情报更新中表示，俄罗斯黑海舰队基地附近的铁路中断可能会影响口径巡航导弹等武器的供应和运送。

据俄罗斯国家通讯社塔斯社报道，一列火车在克里米亚半岛的辛菲罗波尔附近出轨，在“未经授权的个人”的干预下，阻塞了通往位于塞瓦斯托波尔的俄罗斯 BSF 基地的路线。俄罗斯当局目前正在努力解决这一事件。

英国国防部表示：“这一地区的任何破坏活动都将进一步增加克里姆林宫对其保护克里米亚其他关键基础设施能力的担忧。” “半岛在促成俄罗斯在乌克兰发动战争方面保持着至关重要的心理和后勤作用。”

俄罗斯于 2014 年从乌克兰入侵并吞并了该半岛。

— Ruxandra Iordache

欧洲理事会主席警告说，“俄罗斯钻石不会永远存在”

“我们现在的重点是堵住漏洞的大门。并继续切断俄罗斯与关键供应的联系。我们将限制俄罗斯钻石的贸易。俄罗斯钻石不会永远存在，”欧洲理事会主席查尔斯米歇尔说。
蒂埃里·莫纳斯 |盖蒂图片新闻 |盖蒂图片社

欧洲理事会主席查尔斯·米歇尔本周末在日本广岛举行的七国集团峰会之前的新闻发布会上表示，欧盟愿意考虑对俄罗斯钻石实施制裁。

“我们现在的重点是堵住漏洞的大门。并继续切断俄罗斯与关键供应的联系。我们将限制俄罗斯钻石的贸易。俄罗斯钻石不会永远存在，”他说。

迄今为止，欧盟尚未对俄罗斯钻石采取措施，但自莫斯科开始全面入侵乌克兰以来，已对俄罗斯银行业、贸易和能源业实施了几波制裁。

英国于 5 月 18 日宣布有意禁止俄罗斯钻石以及俄罗斯原产铜、铝和镍的进口。

— Ruxandra Iordache

乌克兰官员证实泽伦斯基将亲自出席七国集团峰会

一名乌克兰安全官员证实，该国总统沃洛德米尔·泽连斯基 (Volodymyr Zelenskyy) 将于本周末亲自出席在日本广岛举行的七国集团峰会，这与英国《金融时报》早些时候的报道一致。

乌克兰国家安全与国防委员会秘书 Oleksiy Danilov 在路透社报道的评论中说：“非常重要的事情将在那里决定，因此我们总统的出席对于捍卫我们的利益是绝对必要的。”

世界上最富有的七个国家的官员预计将讨论对俄罗斯实施更严厉的制裁，英国于 5 月 18 日宣布有意禁止俄罗斯钻石以及俄罗斯原产铜、铝和镍的进口。它还计划对另外 86 名个人和公司实施进一步制裁。据欧洲理事会主席查尔斯·米歇尔称，欧盟同样针对俄罗斯钻石实施贸易限制。

— Ruxandra Iordache

拜登政府官员表示，七国集团成员预计将推出针对俄罗斯的新制裁和出口管制

2023 年 4 月 27 日，俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 在俄罗斯莫斯科的 Rudnyovo 工业园区主持了一场关于无人驾驶飞机发展的会议。
米哈伊尔·克利门捷夫 |人造卫星 |路透社

根据白宫制定的基本规则，一位不愿透露姓名的拜登政府高级官员表示，七国集团成员正计划对俄罗斯实施新的制裁和出口管制。

这位高级政府官员在与记者的电话会议上说：“明天你们将听到强有力的声明，表达我们在应对俄罗斯侵略战争时的团结、力量和承诺。”

“我们已经采取一系列行动，与我们的七国集团伙伴协调，追究俄罗斯的责任，我们已经实施了有史以来对主要经济体实施的最大规模的制裁和出口管制行动，”这位官员谈到协调一致时说。自 2 月下旬战争开始以来对莫斯科实施的多轮制裁。

该官员表示，拜登政府也将“推出我们自己的一揽子计划”，但拒绝提供具体细节，只是制裁将解决逃税漏洞。

— 阿曼达·马西亚斯

七国集团峰会将于5月19日至22日在日本广岛举行。
游泳池 |盖蒂图片新闻 |盖蒂图片社

随着俄罗斯连续第二年入侵乌克兰，七国集团领导人已承诺采取一系列进一步措施向俄罗斯施压。

该组织表示：“我们正在实施进一步的制裁和措施，以增加俄罗斯和那些支持其战争努力的国家的成本。”

七国集团领导人在日本广岛举行为期三天的会议，讨论国际贸易和安全，俄罗斯继续在乌克兰发动战争，而美国和中国则在多极世界中争夺影响力。

该组织在周五晚些时候发布的一份声明中表示：“我们将让俄罗斯无法获得支持其战争机器的 G-7 技术、工业设备和服务，”该声明还透露了其对乌克兰战后复苏的经济支持。

新宣布的制裁建立在之前的措施之上，并将扩大到“确保所有对俄罗斯侵略至关重要的物品的出口，包括俄罗斯在战场上使用的物品，在我们所有的司法管辖区内都受到限制，包括工业机械、工具和其他技术的出口俄罗斯用来重建其战争机器，”七国集团在声明中说。

限制措施已公布 预计乌克兰总统泽伦斯基将飞往日本参加七国集团峰会。

乌克兰的复苏预算

七国集团加倍支持乌克兰，宣扬国际组织为重建基辅饱受战争蹂躏的经济所做的改革计划。

“在七国集团轮值主席国日本的领导下，我们与国际社会一道，确保乌克兰获得 2023 年和 2024 年初所需的预算支持，”该集团表示，并补充说，它随时准备“支持可持续和有弹性的复苏和绿色经济”重建乌克兰，包括分享我们在人道主义排雷和与战争相关的碎片和污染管理方面的经验、知识和专业知识。”

国际货币基金组织上个月向乌克兰提供了156 亿美元的贷款，作为支持其经济的 1150 亿美元一揽子计划的一部分。

“我们致力于解决乌克兰的复苏需求。我们将继续共同努力，支持乌克兰修复其关键基础设施、恢复和重建，”七国集团周五表示。

七国集团补充说，它已“大幅减少”对俄罗斯能源供应和商品的依赖。

它在声明中说：“我们决心继续沿着这条道路前进，这样俄罗斯就无法再将能源武器化来对付我们。” “我们将进一步减少对俄罗斯民用核能及相关产品的依赖，包括努力协助寻求供应多元化的国家，”它说。

违禁钻石

这些事态发展是在英国根据将于今年晚些时候出台的立法单独对俄罗斯实施更多制裁之际发生的。

“英国今天宣布禁止俄罗斯钻石，该行业 2021 年出口价值 40 亿美元，以及进口俄罗斯产的铜、铝和镍，”首相里希·苏纳克 (Rishi Sunak) 办公室在周五的新闻稿中表示。

2023 年 5 月 17 日，英国首相 Rishi Sunak 在前往日本参加在广岛举行的七国集团峰会时，在政府专机上对政治记者发表讲话。
斯特凡·卢梭 |法新社 |盖蒂图片社

“正如今天的制裁公告所表明的那样，面对来自俄罗斯的威胁，七国集团仍然团结一致，并坚定地支持乌克兰，”苏纳克说。

G-7 宣布有意限制俄罗斯原产钻石的贸易。

“为了减少俄罗斯从钻石出口中提取的收入，我们将继续密切合作，限制在俄罗斯开采、加工或生产的钻石的贸易和使用，并与主要合作伙伴合作，以确保有效实施未来协调的限制措施，包括通过追踪技术，”该组织说。

“影响最小”

然而，根据乔治华盛顿大学国际事务研究教授罗伯特奥通的说法，挤压俄罗斯经济的额外努力不太可能产生重大影响。

“对俄罗斯的新限制性制裁对世界贸易的影响微乎其微。这些措施都不可能让俄罗斯停止对乌克兰的战争，因为普京完全致力于这一点，而且制裁不会损害俄罗斯在一天内运作的能力-以天为基础，”他在一封电子邮件中说。

“由于中国和印度没有参与制裁，俄罗斯仍然有很多贸易伙伴，”他补充说。

Orttung 指出，如果与对乌克兰的广泛军事援助相结合，加大对俄罗斯经济压力的措施将具有重要的象征意义。

“对世界贸易最有帮助的结果将是阻止俄罗斯进一步侵略的战争的结束，”他说。

“西方为增强乌克兰的战斗力和削弱俄罗斯所做的一切都会使我们更接近这一目标。”

菲律宾央行行长称美联储是“不确定性的一大来源”
Squawk Box 亚洲

菲律宾央行行长费利佩·梅达拉 (Felipe Medalla) 表示，考虑到经济的国内通胀形势，菲律宾央行可能会在接下来的两到三次会议上保持政策利率不变，然后再考虑降息。

这是在周四将基准利率维持在 6.25% 之后，这是自 2022 年 5 月以来连续九次加息后的首次暂停。

Medalla 在接受 CNBC 的“ Squawk Box Asia ”采访时表示，由于月度通胀“实际上已经很低”，央行可以考虑在接下来的两到三次会议后降息。

然而，Medalla 指出，“市场似乎认为我们的政策与美国政策之间的差异在 1% 到 1.25% 之间是合适的。”

“我们必须非常警惕的是，我们的政策利率与美联储的政策利率之间的微小差异可能在多大程度上导致比索大幅走软。”

比索目前兑美元汇率为55.74。

此外，Medalla 还预测该国的通货膨胀率到 9 月或 10 月将降至 4% 左右。菲律宾 4 月份的总体通胀率为 6.6%。

; Fri, 19 May 2023 07:17:13 GMT 107243652 https://www.cnbc.com/2023/05/18/stock-market-today-live-updates.html Samantha Subin Russia's military has adapted and is now a more formidable enemy for Ukraine, defense analysts say
An armored convoy of pro-Russian troops moves along a road during the Ukraine-Russia conflict in the southern port city of Mariupol, Ukraine, on April 21, 2022.
Chingis Kondarov | Reuters

Russia's military has been widely discredited and disparaged by the Western media since the start of its invasion of Ukraine, seen to have bungled the early phase of the war after suffering a series of setbacks and retreats.

But defense analysts at a top London-based military thinktank have investigated Russia's tactical adaptations during the war and have noted that a more structured, coordinated and reactive armed force has emerged — and one that's particularly strong on the defensive.

As such, Russia's military now represents a much more formidable opponent for Ukraine as it prepares to launch a much-anticipated counteroffensive to reclaim occupied territory.

"As Ukraine prepares for offensive operations its armed forces face major tactical challenges," Jack Watling and Nick Reynolds, specialists in land warfare at the Royal United Services Institute (RUSI), said in their latest report, entitled "Russian Tactics in the Second Year of its Invasion of Ukraine."

"The depth of [Russian] defences mean that Ukraine must generate serious combat power in order to penetrate the Russian lines, with the extent of Russian defensive fortifications across the front making bypassing them near-impossible," the report, published Friday, noted.

RUSI's Nick Reynolds told CNBC that while Russia "put themselves in a very bad position at the start of last year," conducting what he described as massive strategic and operational blunders that deprived them of some of their best units and equipment, "since then, the Russian state and the Russian military have put themselves on more of a war footing and have been adapting."

"In particular, a lot of systems and the way they work together are working much better than they were last year. The fact that they're on the defensive now allows them to combine arms in a way that's a little bit easier than coordinating offensive operations. They're also performing [in a way that was] much closer to how they were, pre-war, expected to perform."

"Basically, Ukrainians have a hard challenge out of them," Reynolds said Thursday, saying RUSI expected Russia to employ a large amount of artillery fire to defend its units and "very capable" electronic warfare systems aimed at defeating UAVs, or drones.

These are already proving devastatingly effective, with Ukraine losing as many as 10,000 UAVs a month "due to the effectiveness of Russian Electronic Warfare and extensive use of navigational interference," RUSI said.

Steep learning curve

There's no doubt among Western defense experts that Russia's military campaign in Ukraine in 2022 generally went badly.

Russia bit off far more than it could chew when it tried to invade its neighbor from the north, east and south early last year and was forced to make several humiliating retreats, most notably from the Ukrainian capital Kyiv.

Then later on in the year there were successes for Ukraine as its forces launched counteroffensives to recapture swathes of occupied territory around Kharkiv in the northeast of the country. In October, Russian troops withdrew from part of the Kherson region in the south.

The Russian military's poor performance was widely blamed on poor planning, equipment and logistics and ill-equipped and inadequately trained troops, in insufficient numbers to sustain wide-scale combat operations.

Russia also made a fundamental mistake in underestimating both the resistance Ukraine would mount against Russia and the strength of international support for Kyiv, particularly in terms of the billions of dollars' worth of military hardware.

Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a concert marking the eighth anniversary of Russia's annexation of Crimea from Ukraine at the Luzhniki stadium in Moscow on March 18, 2022.
Mikhail Klimentyev | Afp | Getty Images

Despite Russia's setbacks, President Vladimir Putin and the Kremlin have dug their heels in, ramping up the anti-Ukrainian and anti-Western rhetoric and pitching the war, or "special military operation" as an existential question for Russia and a matter of its survival.

On the battlefield, meanwhile, neither Russia nor Ukraine have been able to claim any significant territorial gains over winter and into spring, with Ukrainian hopes now riding on a counteroffensive to be launched soon, though no one knows when or where it will begin.

RUSI's analysts say Russia's military still has deficiencies and weaknesses — the foremost being low morale across Russian infantry units — but they warned that it would be foolish to ridicule or write-off Russia's armed forces, or to become complacent about their imminent defeat at the hands of Ukraine.

"There's no smoke without fire and parts of the Russian military, particularly their line ground combat formations have performed very poorly, but at the same time they're not useless, they pack a lot of firepower and the Russian military is still in the fight," Reynolds said.

"The components in the Russian military system, particularly some of the ground combat units, are outperformed certainly by NATO military standards, I'd say they also are out-performed by the Ukrainians. And I think, in particular, sort of a lack of a clear rationale for why they're fighting and very poor morale are impediments to the Russians achieving their goal — but they're still in operations and they're still holding ground."

What does this mean for Ukraine's much-anticipated counteroffensive? Reynolds said it was hard and unwise to make predictions but did not underestimate the challenge Ukraine faces, with an expectation of more deadly attritional warfare with steep personnel losses for both sides and slow, grinding gains, or losses, of territory.

"Even if the Ukrainians perform very, very well, they will have to initially breach through Russian defensive lines and they will have to mop up Russian defensive positions. So there'll be attritional fighting, there'll be assaults on fixed defensive positions on some level. So it'll be difficult."

His comments come after New Zealand allocated millions for reconstruction following severe weather events and announced measures aimed at helping people cope with rising cost of living despite a larger-than-expected government deficit.

The country on Thursday forecast a deficit of 7 billion New Zealand dollars ($4.37 billion) for the year ending June 2023, compared to a forecast last December for a deficit of NZ$3.6 billion.

New Zealand is also not projected to return to surplus until 2025-2026, a year later than previously forecast. The Treasury sees inflation slowing to 3.3% by mid-2024, from the current blistering 6.7% pace.

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has warned that a boost in government spending could add to aggressive inflation that has already seen the central bank increase the official cash rate by 500 basis points since October 2021, Reuters reported.

"We've been pretty targeted and the cost-of-living support that we put out in this budget, particularly as you noted around young families, and support for health costs and so on," Robertson told CNBC.

"We very much had in mind to making sure that this budget contributed to inflation coming down."
